sp.l: Who's that? is he vnder my Command?

sp.speaker: CRA.
sp.p: Yes, yes, yes, tis Appetitus; if you go that way, and looke about those thickets, ile go hither, and search this groue, I doubt not but to finde him?

sp.speaker: SOM.
sp.l: Content.

div.stage: Exeunt Somnus, et Crapula.

div.head: ACT. 5. SCEN. 16.
div.stage: APPETITVS, IRRASCIBILIS, with a willowe in his hand pul'd vp by the rootes. SOMNVS, CRAPVLA.
The Senses all a sleepe.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.l: So now's the time that I would gladly meete,
These madding Senses that abus'd mee thus;
What? haunt me like an owle? make an Asse of me?
No they shall know, ●I scorne to serue such masters,
As cannot master their affections,
Their iniurie● haue chang'd my nature,
Now I ●le be no more called hungry parasite:
But he●ceforth answere to the wrathfull name
Of angry Appetite, my choller's vp:
〈◊〉 coole me quickly with thy fanne,
Ore●ce I le cut thy cheekes, why this is braue:
Fa●●e better then to faune at Gustus table,
For a few scrappes, no, no, such words as these,
By Pluto stabbe the villaine, kill the slaue:
By the infernall hagges, Ile hough the rogue,
And paunch the rascall that abusd me thus,
Such words as these fitte angry Appetite.

div.stage: Enter CRAPVLA.

sp.speaker: CRA.
sp.p: Somnus, Somnus, come hether, come hether quickly, hee's here, hee's here.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.l: I marry is he sirra, what of that? base miscreant Cra● pula.

sp.speaker: CRA.
sp.l: O gentle Appetitus.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: You muddy gulche, darst looke me in the face, while mine eyes sparkle, with reuengfull fire? (tiff, toff, tiff, toff,)

sp.speaker: CRA.
sp.l: Good Appetitus.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.l: Peace you fat bawson, peace, (tiff, toff, tiff, toff,)
Seest not this fatall engine of my wrath?
Villaine Ile maule thee for thine old offences,
And grinde thy bones to powder with this pestle:
You when I had no weapons to defend me,
Could beate me out of dores; but now prepare,
Make thy selfe ready, for thou shalt not scape.
Thus doth the great reuengefull Appetite,
Vpon his fatte foe, wreake his wrathfull spite.

div.stage: APPETITVS heaueth vp his club to braine CRAPVLA, but SOMNVS in the meane. time, catcheth him behind and binds him?

sp.speaker: SOM.
sp.l: Why how now Crapula?

sp.speaker: CRA.
sp.l: Am I not dead? is not my soule departed?

sp.speaker: SOM.
sp.p: No, no, see where he lyes, that would haue ●iurt thee? feare nothing?
sp.stage: SOM●●S laies the Senses all in a circle, feele to feete, and wa●ts his wand ouer them,
sp.l: So rest you all in silent quietnesse,
Let nothing wake you till the power of sleepe,
With his sweete dew, cooling your braines inflamed,
Hath rectified the vaine and idle thoughts,
Bred by your surfet, and distemperature:
Loe here the Senses late outragious,
All in a round together sleepe like friends,
For there's no difference twixt the King and Clowne,
The poore and rich, the beautious and deformed,
Wrapt in the vaile of night, and bonds of sleepe,
Without whose powre, and sweete dominion,
Our life were Hell, and pleasure painfulnesse,
The sting of enuie, and the dart of loue,
A●arice talons, and the fire of hate:
Would poison, wound, distract, and soone consume,
The heart, the liuer life and minde of man;
The 〈◊〉 Mower, that with ●rawnie armes,
Wi●●deth the crooked sithe, in many a swathe,
Cutting the flowrie pride on the veluet plaine,
Lies downe at night, and in the weaty folds
Of his wiues armes, forgets his labour past,
The painfull Marriner, and carefull Smith,
The toyling Plowman, all Artificers,
Most humbly yceld to my dominion,
Without due rest, nothing is durable.
Loe thus doth Somnus conquer all the world
With his most awfull waud, and halfe the yeare
Raignes ouer the best and proudest Emperours.
Onely the nurslings of the Sisters nine,
Rebels against me scorne my great command:
And when darke night from her bedewy wings,
Drops sleepie silence to the eyes of all,
They onely wake, and with vnwearied toile,
Labour to finde the Via lac●ea,
That leads to the heauen of immortallitie,
And by the loftie to towring of their minde,
Fledgd with the feathers of a learned muse,
They raise themselues vnto the highest pitch,
Marrying base earth and heauen in a thought;
But thus I punish their rebellion,
Their industrie was neuer yet rewarded,
Better to sleepe then wake, and toile for nothing.

div.stage: Exeunt Somnus & Crapula.

div.head: ACTVS. 5. SCENA. 17.
div.stage: The ●iue Senses, LINGVA, APPETITVS, all a sleepe, and dreaming, PHANTASTES, HEVRESIS.

sp.speaker: AVD.
sp.p: So' ho Rocwood, so ho Rocwood, Rocwood, your Or|gan, hay Chanter, Chanter, by 〈◊〉 hed-tyre it's a very deepe mouth'd dogge, a most admirable crie of hounds, looke here, againe, againe, there, there, ah wa●e counter.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: Do you see the full Moone yonder, and not the man in it, why me thinkes 'tis too, too euident, I see his dogge very plaine, and looke you, iust vnder his taile is a Thorne bush of Furres.

sp.speaker: GVS.
sp.p: 'Twill make a fine tooth-pick: that Larkes heele there, ô do not burne it.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Boy, Heuresis, what think'st thou I thinke, when I thinke nothing?

sp.speaker: HEV.
sp.p: And it please you sir, I thinke you are deuising how to answer a man that askes you nothing.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Well gest boy, but yet thou mistookst it, for I was thinking of the constancie of women, (Ap●titus snoares alowd. Beware sirra, take heede, I doubt me there's some wild Boare lodged here about? how now? mee thinkes these be the Sen|ses, ha? in my conceit the elder brother of death has kist them.

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh, I am stabd, I am stab'd, holde your hand, oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: How now? doe they talke in their sleepe? are they not awake Heuresis?

sp.speaker: HEV.
sp.p: No questionlesse, they be all fast a sleepe.

sp.speaker: GVST.
sp.p: Eate not too many of those Apples, they bee very sl●tiue?

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p: Foh, foh, beate out this Dogge heare, foh, was it you Appetitus?

sp.speaker: AVD.
sp.p: In faith it was most sweetly winded, whosoeuer it was, the warble is very good, and the horne is excellent?

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.p: Put on man, put on, keepe your head warme, 'tis cold.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, st, Heuresis, stirre not sirra.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.p: Shut the doore, the potte runnes ouer, sirra Cooke that will be a sweete Pastie, if you nibble the venison so?

sp.speaker: GVST.
sp.p: Say you so, is a Marrow Pye the Helena of meates? giue meet, if I playe not Paris hang mee, Boye a cleane Trencher?

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Serue vp, serue vp, this is a fatte Rabbet, would I might haue the maiden-head of it, come giue me the ●ish there, who hath medled with these maides? ha?

sp.speaker: OLE.
sp.p: Fie, shut your Snuffers doser for shame, 'tis the worst smell that can be.

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.p: O the crampe, the crampe, the crampe, my legge, my legge.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: I must abroad presently, reach mee my best Neck|lace
presently.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Ah Lingua are you there?

sp.speaker: AVD.
sp.p: Here take this Rope, and Ile helpe the leader close with the second Bell: Fie, fie, there is a goodly peale cleane spoilde.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: Ile lay my life that Gentlewoman is painted: well. well I know it, marke but her nose, doe you not see the complection crack out, I must confesse 'tis a good picture.

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, fie, I pray you leaue, you tickle me so, oh, ah, ha, ha, take away your hands I cannot indure, ah you tickle me, ah, ha, ha, ha, ah.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: Hai, rett, rett, rett, now bird, now,—looke about that bush, she trust her thereabout,—here she is, ware wing Cater, ware wing, auaunt.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: Mum, mum, mum, mum.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: st, sirra take heede you wake her not.

sp.speaker: HEV.
sp.p: I knowe sir shee is fast a sleepe, for her mouth is shutte.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: This 'tis, to venture vpon such vncertainties, to loose so rich a Crowne to no end, well, well.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha, wee shall here auon, where shee lost her
maiden-head, st, boy, my Lord Vicegerent, and Maister Regi|ster are hard by, runne quickly, tell them of this accident, wish them come softly.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: Mendatio neuer talke farther, I doubt'tis past re|couery, and my Robe likewise, I shall neuer haue them againe, well, well.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: How? her Crowne, and her Roabe, neuer recouer them? hum, wast not said to bee left by Memory? ha? I con|iecture here's some knauery-fast lockt with sleepe, in good faith. Was that Crowne and Garment yours L●ngua?

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: I marry were they, and that some body hath felt, and shall feele more, if I liue.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: O strange, she answers in her sleepe to my question, but how come the Senses to striue for it?

sp.speaker: LING
sp.p: Why, I laide vpon purpose in their way, that they might fall together by the eares.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: What a strange thing is this?

div.head: ACT. 5. SCENA. 18.
div.stage: The Senses, APPETITVS and LINGVA a sleepe. PHANTASTES. COMV. SENSVS. MEMORIA. ANAMNESTES.

sp.speaker: PHA
sp.p: st, my Lord, softly, softly, here's the notablest peece of treason discouered, how say you Lingu. set all the Senses at ods, she hath confest it to me in her sleepe.

sp.speaker: COM SEN.
sp.p: Ist possible Maister Register? did you euer know any talke in their sleepe?

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: I remember my Lord many haue done so very oft, but women are troubled, especially with this talking disease, many of them haue I heard answer in their dreames, and tell what they did all day awake.

sp.speaker: ANAM.
sp.p: By the same token, there was a wanton maide, that being askt by her Mother, what such a one did with her so late one night in such a roome, she presently said, that—

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: Peace you vilde rake hell, is such a iest fitte for this company, no more I say sirra.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: My Lord will you belieue your owne eares, you shall heare her answere me, as directly and truely as my be. Lingua, what did you with the Crowne and garments.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: Ile tell thee Mendac●●.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Shee thinkes Mendacio speakes to her, marke nowe, marke howe truely shee will answere: what say you Ma|dame?

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: I say Phantastes is a foolish transparent gull; a meere fanatick nupson in my immagination not worthie to ●it as a Iud|ges assistant.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, howe truely and directly shee an|sweres.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Faw, faw, she dreames now she knowes not what shee saies, I trie her once againe: Madame? what remedie can you haue for your greate losses?

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: O are you come Acrasia? welcome, welcome, boy reach a Cushion sit downe good 〈◊〉? I am so beholding to you, your potion wrought exceedinglie, the senses were so mad, did not you see how they raged about the woods?

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: Hum, Acra●●●? is Acrasia her confederate? my life that witch hath wrought some villany,— Linguariseth in her sleepe, and wa●keth. how's this? is shee a sleepe? haue you seene one walke thus before?

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: It is a very common thinge, I haue seene many sicke of the Peripatetick disease.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: By the same token my Lord, I knewe one that went abroad in his sleepe, bent his bowe, shot at a Magpie, kild her, fetcht his arrowe, came home, lockt the doores, and went to bed againe.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: What should be the reason of it?

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: I remember 〈◊〉 told mee the reason once, as I thinke thus: The nerues that carrie the mouing faculty, from the braines, to the thighes, legges, feete, and armes, are wider farre then the other nerues, wher●ore they are not so easily stopt with the vapours of sleepe, but are night and daie ready to per|forme what fancy shall command them.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: It may bee so, but Phantastes enquire more of Acrasia.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: What did you with the potion Acrasia made you:

sp.speaker: LIN.
sp.p: Gaue it to the Senses, and made them as madde as—well, If I cannot recouer it—let it goe, Ile not leaue them thus.

div.stage: She lies downe againe.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: Boy a wake the Senses there.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.p: Hoe, hoe, Auditus, vp, vp, so hoe, Olfactus haue at your nose, vp Visus, Gustus, Tactus, vp: What can you not feele a pinch? haue at you with a pinne.

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.l: Oh, you stab me, oh,

sp.speaker: COM SEN.
sp.l: Tactus, know you how you came hither:

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.l: No my Lord, not I, this I remember,
We sup't with Gustus, and had wine good store,
Where of I thinke I tasted liberally.
Amongst the rest, wee drunke a composition,
Of a most dellicate, and pleasant rellish,
That made our braynes, somewhat irregular.

div.head: ACT. 5, SCEN. 19.
div.stage: The Senses awake, LINGVA asleepe, COMMVNIS SINSVS MEMORY, PHANTASTES, ANAMNESTES, HEV|RESIS ●rawing CRAPVLA.

sp.speaker: HEV.
sp.p: My Lord, here's a fat rascall was lurking in a bushe very suspitiously, his name he sayes is Crapula.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: Sirrah, speake quickly what you knowe of these troubles,

sp.speaker: CRA,
sp.p: Nothing my Lord, but that the Senses were madde, and that Somnus at my request layd them asleepe, in hope to recouer them.

sp.speaker: COM. SE.
sp.p: Why then tis too euident, Acrasia at Lingua's re|quest, bewitcht the Senses, wake her quickly Heuresis.

sp.speaker: LIN.
sp.p: Heigh ho, out alas, aye mee, where am I? how came I here? where am I? ah.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: Li●gua looke not so strangely vpon the mat|ter, you haue confest in your sleepe, that with a Crowne, and a Roabe, you haue disturb'd t●e Senses, vsing a crafty helpe to enrage them, can you deny it?

sp.speaker: LIN.
sp.p: Aye mee, most miserable wretch, I beseech your Lordship forgiue me.

sp.speaker: COM, SEN
sp.p: No, no, tis a fault vnpardonable,

div.stage: (He consults with Memory)

sp.speaker: PHAN.
sp.p: In my conceipt Lingua, you should seale vp your lippes, when you go to bed, these Feminine tongues be so glibbe.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: Visus, Tactus, and the rest, our former sentence concerning you, wee confirme as irreuocable, and establish the Crowne to you Visus, and the Roabe to you Tactus, but as for you Lingua—

sp.speaker: LIN.
sp.p: Let mee haue mine owne, howsoeuer you determine, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: That may not bee, your goods are fallen into our hands, my sentence cannot bee recall'd, you may see, those that seeke what is not theirs, oftentimes loose what's their owne: Therefore Lingua graunting you your life, I commit you to close prison, in Gustus his house, and charge you Gustus, to keepe her vnder the custody of two strong doores, and euery day till she come to 80. yeares of age, see she be well garded with 30. tall watchmen, without whose licence shee shall by no meanes wagge abroad, neuerthelesse vse her Lady-like, according to her estate.

sp.speaker: PHAN.
sp.p: I pray you my Lord adde this to the iudgement that whensoeuer she obtayneth licence to walke abroad, in token the Tongue was the cause of her offence, let her weare a veluet hood, made iust in the fashion of a great Tongue, in my conceit 'tis a verye pritty Embleme of a Woman,

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.p: My Lord, shee hath a vild boy to her page, a cheefe agent in this treason, his name's Mendatio.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p:
Ha? well, I will inflict this punishment on him for this time, let him be soundly whipt, and euer after though
he shall strengthen his speeches with the sinewes of Truth, yet none shall beleeue him.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: In my imagination my Lord, the Day is dead to the great toe, and in my conceit it growes darke, by which I con|iecture it will be cold, and therefore in my fa●cie, and opinion, 'tis best to repaire to our lodgings.

div.stage: Exeunt omnes, praeter Anamnestes & Appetitus.

div.head: ACTVS. 5. SCENA. 20.
div.stage: ANAMNESTES, APPETITVS a sleepe in a corner.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: What's this? a fellow whispering so closely with the Earth? so, ho, so, ho: Appetitus? faith now I thinke Morpheus himselfe hath beene here, vp with a poxe to you, vp you luske, I haue such newes to tell thee sirta: all the Senses are well, and Lingua is proued guilty, vp, vp, vp, I neuer knew him so fast a sleepe in my life.
sp.l: Nay then haue at you a fresh, (tiff, toff, tiff, toff.)

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Iogge me once againe, and Ile throw this whole messe of pottage in your face, cannot one stand quiet at the dresser for you?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I thinke it's impossible for him to sleepe longer then hee dreames of his victuals. What Appetitus, vp quickly, quickly vp, Appetitus, quickly sirra, (toff, toff, toff, toff,)

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Ile come presently, but I hope youle stay till they bee roasted, will you eate them rawe?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Rosted? ha, ha, ha, ha, vp, vp, vp, away,

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Reach the sauce quickly, here's no Sugar, whaw, wam, oh, ou, oh.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: What neuer wake? (Tiffe, toff, tiff, toff,) wilt neuer be? Then I must trie another way I see.

div.head: Epilogus.
div.l: IVdicious friends, it is so late at night,
I cannot waken hungrie Appetite:
Then since the cloase vpon his rising stands,
Let me obtaine this at your courteous hands,
Trie if the friendly opportunitie,
Of your good will, and gra●ious Plauditie,
With the thrice welcome mumure it shall keepe,
Can begge this prisoner from the bands of sleepe.
div.p: Vpon the Plaudite, APPETITVS awakes, and runnes in after ANAMNESTES.
